abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Rural Savings and
            Loan Rehabilitation Project for Benin was highly
            satisfactory. The project achieved its major objectives, its
            impact on institutional development was substantial,
            sustainability is likely, and the performance of the Bank
            was satisfactory while the Borrower's was highly
            satisfactory. Several lessons can be learned from this
            project. First, the right mix of financial sector policies
            that encourage effective financial intermediation were vital
            to the success of the project. Second, obtaining the
            confidence of the rural population and the real transfer of
            decision making authority to the local level are
            prerequisites for the establishment of a sound savings and
            loan rural cooperative network. Third, significant resources
            should be allocated to institution building and training
            functions in order to lay the foundation for a sustainable
            savings and loan network. Fourth, savings mobilization
            should be made a priority as a basis for future
            sustainability. Fifth, the government should respect the
            autonomy of the cooperatives and encourage self-reliance.
            Sixth, interest rates should be deregulated so that real
            positive interest rates can be charged for the loans.
            Seventh, savings should be kept in the rural areas and not
            be transferred to savings-deficit sectors. Finally, group
            lending yields the best results and is facilitated through
            such things as awareness campaigns.
